Genesis.date_academic_stance: Traditional date; low consensus in modern critical scholarship
Genesis.author: Moses (traditional); multiple sources (critical)
Genesis.jesus_revealed: Promised Seed who crushes the serpent; Creator-Word foreshadowed.
Genesis.application: Trust God’s sovereign plan and covenant faithfulness.
Genesis.setting: Primeval history and patriarchal period across Mesopotamia, Canaan, and Egypt.
Genesis.audience: Israelites under the covenant, learning origins and identity.
Genesis.debate: Documentary Hypothesis vs. Mosaic authorship; dating and sources.

Exodus.date_academic_stance: Traditional date; debated, with many scholars favoring later composition
Exodus.author: Moses (traditional); composite sources (critical)
Exodus.jesus_revealed: Passover Lamb; Deliverer who leads out of slavery.
Exodus.application: Live as redeemed people who worship in holiness.
Exodus.setting: Egypt, Red Sea, and wilderness of Sinai.
Exodus.audience: Israel delivered from slavery and constituted as God’s people.
Exodus.debate: Historical exodus timing (15th vs. 13th c.), route, and composition.

Leviticus.date_academic_stance: Traditional date; textual compilation likely later
Leviticus.author: Moses (traditional); priestly compilers/redactors (critical)
Leviticus.jesus_revealed: High Priest and perfect sacrifice who makes us holy.
Leviticus.application: Approach God through the atonement He provides.
Leviticus.setting: Israel encamped at Sinai around the tabernacle.
Leviticus.audience: Priests and people of Israel learning holy worship.
Leviticus.debate: Dating of Priestly material; function of sacrificial system.

Numbers.author: Moses (traditional); later editorial shaping (critical)
Numbers.jesus_revealed: Bronze Serpent lifted up; faithful Presence in the wilderness.
Numbers.application: Persevere in faith; unbelief brings loss, trust brings life.
Numbers.setting: Sinai to wilderness wanderings to the plains of Moab.
Numbers.audience: Second generation of Israelites preparing to enter the land.
Numbers.debate: Wilderness itinerary, census data, and source layers.

Deuteronomy.date_academic_stance: Traditional date; some scholars date later
Deuteronomy.author: Moses (traditional); Deuteronomistic circle (critical)
Deuteronomy.jesus_revealed: Prophet like Moses who speaks God’s final word.
Deuteronomy.application: Love the Lord wholeheartedly and obey His word.
Deuteronomy.setting: Plains of Moab; Moses’ farewell addresses and covenant renewal.
Deuteronomy.audience: Israel poised to enter the Promised Land.
Deuteronomy.debate: Josianic composition hypothesis; covenant-law form and dating.

Joshua.date_academic_stance: Traditional range; debated in academic circles
Joshua.author: Joshua (traditional); Deuteronomistic historians (critical)
Joshua.jesus_revealed: Captain of the Lord’s army; giver of rest and inheritance.
Joshua.application: Be strong and courageous in obedience to God’s promises.
Joshua.audience: Israel settling the land and recalling God’s faithfulness.
Joshua.debate: Conquest vs. gradual settlement/peasant-revolt models; archaeology.

Judges.date_academic_stance: Intermediate consensus; dates uncertain but within this range
Judges.author: Samuel (traditional); Deuteronomistic editors (critical)
Judges.jesus_revealed: True Judge and Deliverer greater than all saviors.
Judges.application: Reject doing what is right in our own eyes; seek God’s kingship.
Judges.setting: Tribal period in Canaan between Joshua and the monarchy.
Judges.audience: Israel warned about covenant unfaithfulness and need for godly rule.
Judges.debate: Chronology of judges, cycles, and redactional shaping.

Ruth.author: Samuel (traditional); unknown/anonymous (critical)
Ruth.jesus_revealed: Kinsman-Redeemer who brings outsiders into God’s family.
Ruth.application: Practice loyal love; God works redemption through faithfulness.
Ruth.setting: Bethlehem and Moab during the time of the judges.
Ruth.audience: Israel reflecting on David’s lineage and God’s providence.
Ruth.debate: Date (monarchic vs. postexilic), purpose, and genre (novella vs. history).

1 Samuel.date_academic_stance: Approximate traditional dating; composition possibly later
1 Samuel.author: Samuel, Gad, Nathan (traditional); Deuteronomistic historians (critical)
1 Samuel.jesus_revealed: Anointed King after God’s heart, prefigured by David.
1 Samuel.application: God exalts the humble and opposes the proud.
1 Samuel.setting: Transition from judges to monarchy; Shiloh, Philistia, Bethlehem.
1 Samuel.audience: Israel learning about kingship and obedience.
1 Samuel.debate: Sources behind Saul/David cycles; historical reliability; redaction.

2 Samuel.author: Gad, Nathan (traditional); Deuteronomistic editors (critical)
2 Samuel.jesus_revealed: Son of David whose throne endures forever.
2 Samuel.application: Hope in God’s covenant mercy despite human failure.
2 Samuel.setting: David’s reign from Hebron and Jerusalem; regional conflicts.
2 Samuel.audience: Israel under the monarchy, looking to the Davidic promise.
2 Samuel.debate: Court history sources; chronology; composition and theology of the narrative.

1 Kings.author: Jeremiah (traditional); Deuteronomistic historians (critical)
1 Kings.jesus_revealed: Wisdom greater than Solomon; faithful temple presence.
1 Kings.application: Seek God’s wisdom; idolatry destroys kingdoms.
1 Kings.setting: United monarchy under Solomon, divided kingdom afterward.
1 Kings.audience: Israel and Judah reflecting on covenant faithfulness.
1 Kings.debate: Historical Solomon; archaeology of temple and chronology of kings.

2 Kings.author: Jeremiah (traditional); Deuteronomistic historians (critical)
2 Kings.jesus_revealed: Prophetic Word who judges sin and preserves a remnant.
2 Kings.application: Turn from idols; trust God’s warning and mercy.
2 Kings.setting: Divided monarchy until the Babylonian exile.
2 Kings.audience: Israel in exile seeking explanation for judgment.
2 Kings.debate: Exilic redaction; relation to Chronicles and prophetic books.

1 Chronicles.date_academic_stance: High academic consensus on postexilic composition
1 Chronicles.author: Ezra (traditional); anonymous Chronicler (critical)
1 Chronicles.jesus_revealed: Promised Son of David; focus on worship and priestly kingdom.
1 Chronicles.application: Center life on worship and God’s promises.
1 Chronicles.setting: Postexilic Judah, with temple worship as focal point.
1 Chronicles.audience: Returned exiles seeking encouragement in covenant faithfulness.
1 Chronicles.debate: Theology of temple vs. Samuel-Kings narrative differences.

2 Chronicles.date_academic_stance: High academic consensus on postexilic composition
2 Chronicles.author: Ezra (traditional); anonymous Chronicler (critical)
2 Chronicles.jesus_revealed: Faithful King sought by those who humble themselves and pray.
2 Chronicles.application: Seek God in repentance; He heals and restores.
2 Chronicles.setting: Postexilic Judah recounting history with theological emphasis.
2 Chronicles.audience: Community of returned exiles encouraged to seek God.
2 Chronicles.debate: Chronicler’s selective retelling of Kings; theological motive.

Ezra.author: Ezra (traditional); anonymous compiler (critical)
Ezra.jesus_revealed: Restorer of the temple—God dwelling with His people.
Ezra.application: Devote yourself to study, obedience, and teaching God’s word.
Ezra.setting: Return from Babylonian exile; rebuilding of temple.
Ezra.audience: Returned exiles seeking purity and covenant renewal.

Nehemiah.author: Nehemiah (traditional); combined with Ezra material (critical)
Nehemiah.jesus_revealed: Rebuilder of ruined walls—restorer of people.
Nehemiah.application: Work with prayerful resolve to rebuild what’s broken.
Nehemiah.setting: Jerusalem during Persian period; rebuilding city walls.
Nehemiah.audience: Exiles returning to rebuild city and community.
Nehemiah.debate: Unity of Ezra-Nehemiah; role of memoir sources.

Esther.date_academic_stance: Traditional dating with some scholarly debate
Esther.author: Unknown (traditional: Mordecai); anonymous (critical)
Esther.jesus_revealed: Hidden Providence who preserves His people from destruction.
Esther.application: Trust God’s unseen hand; act with courage in your moment.
Esther.audience: Jews in diaspora encouraged in God’s providence.
Esther.debate: Historic vs. literary tale; absence of God’s name.

Job.date_academic_stance: Uncertain; final form likely from 700–400 BC
Job.author: Job (traditional); anonymous sage (critical)
Job.application: Fear God in mystery and suffering; He is wise and just.
Job.setting: Patriarchal setting in Uz; dialogues with friends.
Job.audience: Believers wrestling with suffering and divine justice.
Job.debate: Dating of composition; prose frame vs. poetic core.

Psalms.author: David, Asaph, others (traditional); multiple authors/editors (critical)
Psalms.jesus_revealed: Anointed King, Good Shepherd, and Suffering Messiah.
Psalms.application: Pray all of life—lament, praise, and trust—in God’s presence.
Psalms.setting: Temple worship and personal devotion across centuries.
Psalms.audience: Israel in worship; believers seeking expression before God.
Psalms.debate: Davidic authorship scope; editorial shaping into five books.

Proverbs.author: Solomon (traditional); sages/collectors (critical)
Proverbs.application: Pursue the fear of the Lord and skill for godly living.
Proverbs.setting: Royal court wisdom traditions and later compilations.
Proverbs.audience: Young people and community seeking wisdom and discipline.
Proverbs.debate: Extent of Solomonic authorship; date of final compilation.

Ecclesiastes.author: Solomon (traditional); anonymous 'Qoheleth' (critical)
Ecclesiastes.jesus_revealed: True meaning beyond vanity; eternal Shepherd of souls.
Ecclesiastes.application: Fear God and keep His commandments amid life’s vapor.
Ecclesiastes.setting: Royal or wisdom tradition context; reflection on human toil.
Ecclesiastes.audience: Israelites reflecting on meaning and mortality.
Ecclesiastes.debate: Authorship, dating, and coherence of its pessimistic tone.

Song of Solomon.author: Solomon (traditional); anonymous (critical)
Song of Solomon.jesus_revealed: Bridegroom who delights in His people.
Song of Solomon.application: Honor covenant love; reflect Christ’s love for His bride.
Song of Solomon.setting: Love poetry with royal and pastoral imagery.
Song of Solomon.audience: Israel, celebrating covenantal love and intimacy.
Song of Solomon.debate: Allegory vs. literal love poetry; authorship.

Isaiah.author: Isaiah son of Amoz (traditional); multiple contributors (critical)
Isaiah.jesus_revealed: Holy King and Suffering Servant who saves.
Isaiah.application: Trust the Servant-King; await His righteous kingdom.
Isaiah.setting: Judah during Assyrian threat; later exilic/postexilic additions.
Isaiah.audience: Judah and nations; future exiles and returnees.
Isaiah.debate: Unity vs. Deutero- and Trito-Isaiah; messianic interpretations.

Jeremiah.author: Jeremiah (traditional); Baruch as scribe (critical)
Jeremiah.jesus_revealed: Mediator of the New Covenant written on hearts.
Jeremiah.application: Return to God; He gives new hearts and steadfast hope.
Jeremiah.setting: Judah before and during Babylonian invasion.
Jeremiah.audience: Judah and exiles facing judgment and restoration.
Jeremiah.debate: Two textual traditions (MT vs. LXX); arrangement differences.

Lamentations.author: Jeremiah (traditional); anonymous poet (critical)
Lamentations.jesus_revealed: Man of Sorrows bearing our griefs.
Lamentations.application: Grieve sin and cling to God’s mercies that never end.
Lamentations.audience: Exiles mourning the fall of Jerusalem.

Ezekiel.author: Ezekiel (traditional); priest-prophet in exile
Ezekiel.jesus_revealed: Glory of God and Shepherd-King who gives a new spirit.
Ezekiel.application: Receive a new heart and walk by the Spirit.
Ezekiel.setting: Babylonian exile along the Kebar River.
Ezekiel.debate: Visionary symbolism; temple vision historic vs. eschatological.

Daniel.date_academic_stance: Traditional date; critical scholarship favors later 2nd century BC
Daniel.author: Daniel (traditional); anonymous apocalyptic seer (critical)
Daniel.jesus_revealed: Son of Man to whom dominion is given.
Daniel.application: Remain faithful in exile; God rules over kings.
Daniel.audience: Jews in exile encouraged by God’s sovereignty.
Daniel.debate: Prophecy vs. vaticinium ex eventu; apocalyptic dating.

Hosea.author: Hosea (traditional); prophet in Israel
Hosea.jesus_revealed: Faithful Husband who redeems an unfaithful people.
Hosea.application: Return to the Lord; His love heals and restores.
Hosea.audience: Israel, warning of judgment yet hope of restoration.
Hosea.debate: Structure of oracles; symbolic marriage accounts.

Joel.author: Joel son of Pethuel (traditional); unknown (critical)
Joel.jesus_revealed: Spirit-baptizer pouring out power on all flesh.
Joel.application: Repent and call on the Lord; He restores years lost.
Joel.setting: Judah during locust plague and drought.
Joel.audience: Judah, exhorted to repent and await God’s Spirit.
Joel.debate: Dating (preexilic vs. postexilic); order of chapters.

Amos.author: Amos, shepherd from Tekoa (traditional/critical)
Amos.jesus_revealed: Righteous Judge who restores David’s fallen tent.
Amos.application: Let justice roll down; true worship includes justice.
Amos.audience: Israel warned of judgment for injustice.
Amos.debate: Extent of later redaction; links to Deuteronomistic editors.

Obadiah.author: Obadiah (traditional); unknown (critical)
Obadiah.jesus_revealed: Judge of the nations and Savior of Zion.
Obadiah.application: God humbles the proud and preserves His people.
Obadiah.setting: Judah after destruction of Jerusalem, judgment on Edom.
Obadiah.debate: Dating tied to either Babylonian destruction (586 BC) or earlier conflicts.

Jonah.author: Jonah son of Amittai (traditional); anonymous narrator (critical)
Jonah.jesus_revealed: Sign of three days—death and resurrection for the nations.
Jonah.application: Share God’s mercy with enemies; His grace is sovereign.
Jonah.setting: Nineveh and sea voyage; Assyrian empire context.
Jonah.audience: Israelites reminded of God’s mercy to nations.
Jonah.debate: Historical prophet vs. parabolic story; date of writing.

Micah.author: Micah of Moresheth (traditional/critical)
Micah.jesus_revealed: Ruler from Bethlehem; requirement of justice, mercy, humility.
Micah.application: Walk humbly with God; hope in the coming Shepherd-King.
Micah.setting: Judah during reigns of Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah.
Micah.audience: Judah and Israel warned of judgment and given hope.
Micah.debate: Later additions debated; messianic prophecies scrutinized.

Nahum.author: Nahum of Elkosh (traditional/critical)
Nahum.jesus_revealed: Avenger of evil and refuge for the oppressed.
Nahum.application: Take refuge in the Lord; He will right every wrong.
Nahum.setting: Prophecy against Nineveh during Assyrian dominance.
Nahum.audience: Judah and nations oppressed by Assyria.
Nahum.debate: Exact location of Elkosh and date refinement debated.

Habakkuk.author: Habakkuk (traditional/critical)
Habakkuk.jesus_revealed: Righteous One by whom the righteous live by faith.
Habakkuk.application: Trust God’s timing; rejoice though fig trees fail.
Habakkuk.audience: Judah struggling with God’s justice and judgment.
Habakkuk.debate: Structure as dialogue or lament; placement in prophetic corpus.

Zephaniah.author: Zephaniah (traditional/critical)
Zephaniah.jesus_revealed: Mighty One who saves and rejoices over His people.
Zephaniah.application: Seek the Lord; He sings over the humble and repentant.
Zephaniah.setting: Judah during reign of Josiah, just before reforms.
Zephaniah.audience: Judah warned of coming Day of the Lord.
Zephaniah.debate: Extent of Josianic influence; relation to Deuteronomistic theology.

Haggai.date_academic_stance: High scholarly consensus on postexilic date
Haggai.author: Haggai (traditional/critical)
Haggai.jesus_revealed: Greater glory of the latter temple fulfilled in Christ.
Haggai.application: Put God’s house first; He supplies glory and peace.
Haggai.setting: Jerusalem after return from exile; rebuilding the temple.
Haggai.audience: Returned exiles challenged to prioritize God’s house.
Haggai.debate: Precise dating and relation to Zechariah.

Zechariah.author: Zechariah (traditional); possible multiple contributors (critical)
Zechariah.application: Look on Him whom we pierced; expect the coming King.
Zechariah.audience: Returned exiles awaiting God’s future kingdom.
Zechariah.debate: Unity of chapters 9–14 with earlier visions.

Malachi.author: Malachi (traditional); anonymous compiler (critical)
Malachi.jesus_revealed: Sun of Righteousness who brings healing.
Malachi.application: Return to the Lord; honor Him in worship and life.
Malachi.audience: Complacent priests and people needing covenant renewal.
Malachi.debate: Identity of Malachi (name vs. title); dating precision.

Matthew.date_academic_stance: Traditional; some scholars date later (80–90 AD)
Matthew.author: Matthew the apostle (traditional); anonymous (critical)
Matthew.jesus_revealed: Messiah-King, fulfillment of the Law and Prophets.
Matthew.application: Follow the King; live the ethics of the kingdom.
Matthew.setting: Written to Jewish-Christian audience under Roman rule.
Matthew.audience: Jewish believers and early church communities.
Matthew.debate: Order of Gospel composition; dependence on Mark/Q-source.

Mark.date_academic_stance: Traditional; majority scholars prefer c. 66–70 AD
Mark.author: John Mark, associate of Peter (traditional); anonymous (critical)
Mark.jesus_revealed: Servant-Son who gives His life as a ransom.
Mark.application: Follow Jesus in sacrificial service and urgency.
Mark.setting: Likely written in Rome during persecution.
Mark.audience: Gentile believers facing suffering and persecution.
Mark.debate: Ending of Mark (shorter vs. longer); priority of Mark in synoptics.

Luke.author: Luke the physician, companion of Paul (traditional); anonymous (critical)
Luke.jesus_revealed: Savior for all nations; compassionate Healer.
Luke.application: Join Jesus’ mission to seek and save the lost.
Luke.setting: Possibly Antioch, Rome, or another Gentile setting.
Luke.debate: Sources (Mark, Q, special L); historicity of infancy narratives.

John.author: John the apostle (traditional); Johannine community (critical)
John.jesus_revealed: Word made flesh; Son of God who gives eternal life.
John.application: Believe and have life in His name.
John.setting: Likely written from Ephesus or Asia Minor.
John.audience: Churches needing assurance of faith in Christ.
John.debate: Authorship, relation to synoptics, prologue vs. later additions.

Acts.date_academic_stance: Traditional; some scholars prefer late 80s AD
Acts.author: Luke the physician (traditional); anonymous (critical)
Acts.jesus_revealed: Risen Lord who pours out the Spirit and builds His church.
Acts.application: Be Spirit-empowered witnesses to the ends of the earth.
Acts.setting: Jerusalem to Rome, tracing expansion of early church.
Acts.debate: Historical reliability; relation to Paul’s letters.

Romans.author: Paul the apostle (traditional/critical consensus)
Romans.jesus_revealed: Righteousness of God revealed through faith in Christ.
Romans.application: Live by faith; present your body as a living sacrifice.
Romans.setting: Written from Corinth during Paul’s third missionary journey.
Romans.audience: Christians in Rome, both Jews and Gentiles.
Romans.debate: Integrity of chapters 15–16; purpose (theological treatise vs. missionary support).

1 Corinthians.author: Paul the apostle (traditional/critical consensus)
1 Corinthians.jesus_revealed: Crucified and risen wisdom and power of God.
1 Corinthians.application: Pursue holiness and love; build up Christ’s body.
1 Corinthians.setting: Written from Ephesus during Paul’s third missionary journey.
1 Corinthians.audience: Church in Corinth facing divisions and moral issues.
1 Corinthians.debate: Unity of the letter; interpolation theories.

2 Corinthians.author: Paul the apostle (traditional/critical consensus)
2 Corinthians.jesus_revealed: Suffering Servant whose grace is sufficient.
2 Corinthians.application: Boast in weakness; ministry flows from God’s power.
2 Corinthians.setting: Written from Macedonia after painful visits to Corinth.
2 Corinthians.audience: Church in Corinth needing reconciliation and encouragement.
2 Corinthians.debate: Possibly composite of multiple letters; tone variations.

Galatians.author: Paul the apostle (traditional/critical consensus)
Galatians.jesus_revealed: Redeemer who frees from the curse of the law.
Galatians.application: Stand firm in gospel freedom; walk by the Spirit.
Galatians.setting: Likely written from Antioch or Corinth.
Galatians.audience: Churches of Galatia struggling with Judaizers’ influence.
Galatians.debate: North vs. South Galatia theory; chronology relative to Acts 15.

Ephesians.author: Paul (traditional); disputed by some scholars (critical)
Ephesians.jesus_revealed: Head of the church; unites all things in Himself.
Ephesians.application: Live your new identity; maintain unity in love.
Ephesians.debate: Authenticity, style, and relation to Colossians.

Philippians.author: Paul the apostle (traditional/critical consensus)
Philippians.jesus_revealed: Exalted Lord who humbled Himself to the cross.
Philippians.application: Pursue joyful humility and gospel partnership.
Philippians.audience: Church at Philippi, Paul’s first European congregation.
Philippians.debate: Unity of the letter (one vs. multiple letters).

Colossians.author: Paul (traditional); disputed by some scholars (critical)
Colossians.jesus_revealed: Image of the invisible God; fullness of deity in bodily form.
Colossians.application: Root your life in Christ, not human tradition.
Colossians.debate: Authorship questioned due to vocabulary/style similarities with Ephesians.

1 Thessalonians.author: Paul the apostle (traditional/critical consensus)
1 Thessalonians.jesus_revealed: Returning Lord who sanctifies His people completely.
1 Thessalonians.application: Live in hope and holiness awaiting His coming.
1 Thessalonians.setting: Written from Corinth during Paul’s second missionary journey.
1 Thessalonians.audience: Young church in Thessalonica facing persecution.
1 Thessalonians.debate: None significant; earliest Pauline letter consensus.

2 Thessalonians.author: Paul (traditional); disputed in critical scholarship
2 Thessalonians.application: Stand firm; do not be shaken by false reports.
2 Thessalonians.setting: Likely written from Corinth shortly after 1 Thessalonians.
2 Thessalonians.audience: Church in Thessalonica clarifying eschatological confusion.

1 Timothy.author: Paul (traditional); later disciple (critical)
1 Timothy.jesus_revealed: One Mediator between God and mankind.
1 Timothy.application: Guard sound doctrine; lead with integrity.
1 Timothy.audience: Timothy in Ephesus, charged to lead the church.
1 Timothy.debate: Authorship and date heavily disputed in scholarship.

2 Timothy.author: Paul (traditional); later disciple (critical)
2 Timothy.jesus_revealed: Faithful Lord who guards the good deposit.
2 Timothy.application: Endure hardship; preach the word in season and out.
2 Timothy.setting: Written from Roman prison shortly before Paul’s death (traditional).
2 Timothy.audience: Timothy, encouraged to endure as a faithful minister.
2 Timothy.debate: Authenticity, style, and historical fit debated.

Titus.author: Paul (traditional); later disciple (critical)
Titus.jesus_revealed: Savior who trains us to live godly lives.
Titus.application: Devote to good works as fruit of grace.
Titus.setting: Written after Paul’s release, possibly from Macedonia.
Titus.audience: Titus in Crete, organizing church leadership.
Titus.debate: Authorship questioned due to vocabulary and church structure.

Philemon.author: Paul the apostle (traditional/critical consensus)
Philemon.application: Practice gospel reconciliation and costly forgiveness.
Philemon.audience: Philemon and the church in his house at Colossae.
Philemon.debate: Interpretation of slavery; minor authenticity debates.

Hebrews.date_academic_stance: Debated authorship and date; consensus on 1st century
Hebrews.author: Anonymous (traditional: Paul, Barnabas, Apollos; critical: unknown)
Hebrews.jesus_revealed: Great High Priest and final sacrifice.
Hebrews.application: Draw near with confidence; hold fast to Christ.
Hebrews.setting: Written to Jewish Christians facing persecution.
Hebrews.audience: Jewish believers tempted to revert to Judaism.
Hebrews.debate: Authorship and audience debated; relation to temple practices.

James.author: James the Just, brother of Jesus (traditional); disputed by some scholars (critical)
James.jesus_revealed: Lord of glory whose wisdom produces works of faith.
James.application: Be doers of the word; pursue wholehearted integrity.
James.audience: Jewish Christians dispersed among the nations.
James.debate: Faith vs. works tension with Paul; authorship questioned.

1 Peter.author: Peter the apostle (traditional); disputed (critical)
1 Peter.jesus_revealed: Cornerstone; example of suffering unto glory.
1 Peter.application: Endure trials; live holy among the nations.
1 Peter.audience: Scattered Christians in Asia Minor facing persecution.
1 Peter.debate: Authorship due to polished Greek style.

2 Peter.date_academic_stance: Late date; debated and likely pseudepigraphal
2 Peter.author: Peter (traditional); widely disputed (critical)
2 Peter.jesus_revealed: Coming Lord; Word more sure than spectacles.
2 Peter.application: Grow in grace; watch for false teachers.
2 Peter.setting: Final exhortation before Peter’s death (traditional view).
2 Peter.audience: Believers needing warning against false teachers.
2 Peter.debate: Authorship strongly disputed; relation to Jude.

1 John.author: John the apostle (traditional); Johannine community (critical)
1 John.jesus_revealed: Incarnate Life; God is light and love in Him.
1 John.application: Abide in truth and love; assurance in the Son.
1 John.debate: Authorship and relation to Gospel of John.

2 John.author: John the apostle (traditional); Johannine elder (critical)
2 John.jesus_revealed: Truth incarnate; doctrine of Christ protects the church.
2 John.application: Walk in truth and love; do not receive deceivers.
2 John.audience: The 'elect lady' and her children (church community).

3 John.author: John the apostle (traditional); Johannine elder (critical)
3 John.jesus_revealed: Lord who commends faithful hospitality and truth.
3 John.application: Support gospel workers; imitate good, not evil.
3 John.audience: Gaius, a church leader; contrasted with Diotrephes.
3 John.debate: Relation to 2 John and Johannine community context.

Jude.author: Jude, brother of Jesus (traditional); disputed (critical)
Jude.jesus_revealed: Lord who keeps His people and judges falsehood.
Jude.application: Contend for the faith; rest in His keeping power.

Revelation.author: John the apostle (traditional); John of Patmos (critical)
Revelation.jesus_revealed: Alpha and Omega; slain Lamb and reigning King.
Revelation.application: Conquer by faithful witness; await the new creation.
Revelation.setting: Patmos, visions of heaven and earth’s consummation.
Revelation.audience: Seven churches of Asia Minor under persecution.
Revelation.debate: Date of writing (Neronian vs. Domitian); symbolism vs. futurism.
